text: Use "〜です/〜ます" for polite statements; it's the standard polite ending for everyday conversation.
"〜ません" is the polite negative form of verbs, used to say something doesn't happen.
"〜たい" attaches to a verb stem to express "want to do" something.
"〜てもいいです" means "it's okay to" and grants permission.
"〜てはいけません" means "must not" and is used for prohibitions.
"〜ながら" connects actions to show two things happening at the same time.
"〜たことがある" expresses past experience, like "have done" something before.
"〜てしまう" can show completion or regret about an action.
"〜そうです" can report hearsay ("I heard that...").
"〜ようです" means "it seems like" and is based on observation.
"〜でしょう" adds probability or softens statements, like "probably".
"〜つもり" expresses intent, like "I plan to" do something.
"〜なければならない" means "must" or "have to" do something.
"〜なくてもいい" means "don't have to" and lifts an obligation.
"〜てくれる" indicates someone does a favor for the speaker.
"〜てもらう" means "receive a favor" from someone.
"〜てあげる" shows the speaker does a favor for someone else.
"〜ようと思う" expresses a decision made at the moment of speaking.
"〜なら" means "if" or "in the case of" and often gives advice.
"〜たら" is a conditional "if/when" that also expresses sequence.
"〜ば" forms a conditional meaning "if" in a general sense.
"〜ても" means "even if" or "even though".
"〜のに" expresses contrast or regret, similar to "even though".
"〜ので" gives a reason in a polite or softer way than "から".
"〜たところ" can mean "just did" something and observed a result.
"〜まま" means "as is" or "unchanged".
"〜ばかり" means "just" (in terms of time) or "only" depending on context.
"〜すぎる" attaches to verbs or adjectives to mean "too much".
"〜らしい" can mean "seems" or describe a typical characteristic.
"〜おう/〜よう" is the volitional form, used to say "let's" or "I will".
"〜ところ" refers to a point in time, like "about to", "in the middle of", or "just finished".
"〜たり〜たり" lists representative actions, like "do things like A and B".
"〜ていく/〜てくる" shows direction or change over time, like "will start" or "have been".
"〜ように" can express purpose, like "in order to" or "so that".
"〜ために" also means "for the sake of" and explains purpose or reason.
"〜ことにする" expresses a decision, like "decide to".
"〜ことになる" indicates something was decided (by others or circumstances).
"〜に違いない" means "must be" or "no doubt".
"〜かもしれない" means "might be" or "maybe".
"〜うちに" means "while" or "before" something changes.
"〜ことができる" expresses ability, like "can do".
"〜ことがある" means "sometimes" when talking about habitual actions.
"〜にくい" attaches to verb stems to mean "hard to do".
"〜やすい" attaches to verb stems to mean "easy to do".
"〜ておく" means "do in advance" or "leave as is".
"〜にする" means "decide on" a choice or selection.
"〜に決まっている" means "must be" or "definitely".
"〜そうだ" can indicate appearance, like "it looks like".
"〜ながらも" means "even while" or "though" (contrast).
"〜わけではない" means "not necessarily" or "it's not that".
"〜というより" means "rather than" or "more like".
"〜おかげで" expresses gratitude for a cause, "thanks to".
"〜せいで" indicates a negative cause, "because of".
"〜ほど" can express degree, like "so... that".
"〜ば〜ほど" means "the more... the more...".
